title: Fundamental limits on nonequilibrium sensing
abstract:
The performance of equilibrium sensors is restricted by the laws of
equilibrium thermodynamics. We here investigate the physical limits on
nonequilibrium sensing in bipartite systems with nonreciprocal coupling. We
show that one of the subsystems, acting as a Maxwell's demon, can significantly
suppress the fluctuations of the other subsystem relative to its response to an
external perturbation. Such negative violation of the fluctuation-dissipation
relation can considerably improve the signal-to-noise ratio above its
corresponding equilibrium value, allowing the subsystem to operate as an
enhanced sensor. We find that the nonequilibrium signal-to-noise ratio of
linear systems may be arbitrary large at low frequencies, even at a fixed
overall amount of dissipation.
